texts.definition: The insertion of game elements into game instances.
markups: <style="Definition">The insertion of game elements into game instances.</style>

Some games introduce new things into the game environment as gameplay progresses. This <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> can be used to gradually introduce challenges, let players build  constructions, or provide surprised to players.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

The ancient board game Go starts with an empty board which players gradually fill with their stones until placing more stone no longer lets players claim parts of the game area. While all the stones belong to specific sets of the game and are inserted into them, in Warhammer Fantasy Battle and Magic: The Gathering players have to bring their own miniatures and cards respectively that they want to use and thereby create game instance by inserting elements (besides possibly then inserting them into the actual battle. Roleplaying games such as Dungeons & Dragons often have some initial locations with enemies and treasures placed and which can thus be said to be part of the game instances, but to these are added player characters and random encounters, and for campaigns game masters need to add new locations and monsters as well.

The game worlds found in MUDs such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style> are constructed by designers and trusted players. While this is done in modes outside the normal gameplay, in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> this is part of the main gameplay (although for the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> this is a separate gameplay mode).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neuroshima%20Hex!">Neuroshima Hex!</link></style> lets players choose from one out of three hex tiles to use each turn, and most of these are units that are to be placed upon the battlefield the constitutes the game's world.

Computer games quite often make use of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> since the computer easily can handle these. Some are preplanned by designers, e.g. players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%204">Quake 4</link></style> several times experience enemies materializes in front of them only to seconds later also have the same thing happen behind them. In other cases, the time and place of elements appearing are random (even if following certain rules) - an example of this can be found in the power-ups of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mario%20Kart%20series">Mario Kart series</link></style>. The power of computers to handle great amount of units does not only make it possible for players to encounter these numbers of enemies; games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires%20series">Age of Empires series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style> show how players can be put in control of large armies.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> consists of considering what game elements should be allowed to be inserted and what mechanism govern when they can be inserted. A special case of the latter is when players construct the actual game instances by the game elements they insert. This is a form of <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, where players either put together sets of game elements as strategies (as for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%2040K">Warhammer 40K</link></style>) or encode them in <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crobots">Crobots</link></style>). Another special case is when the <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> is permanent in the sense that it changes future game instances; this is a typical way in which <style="Link"><link="legacy-games">Legacy Games</link></style> are constructed.

All types of game elements can be used for <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> but not too surprising those that are found in greater number in games are also used together with the pattern more often. This makes <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> common objects of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style>. In this they are <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> and the insertion of them may through the use of <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style> or various means of making the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating Resources</link></style>. Some of these can quite naturally be <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> under other players' control, while others again can be under the control of <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> and then <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> is a common mechanic to introduce new elements. A weak example of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> is how <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> introduced <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> into actual gameplay, this is not a strong example due to the <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> typically being <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> and therefore affecting gameplay even before they can be used. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style> is a stronger example since the <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> not introduced into a game instance will in most cases not be part of it.

The presences of goals such as <style="Link"><link="alignment">Alignment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enclosure">Enclosure</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style> all heavily affect how player will use <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style>, so the presence of these needs to be considered when designing for this pattern.

Less common as <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> is the introduction of <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> but these may more important in relation to <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> (but they can also be improvised to be part of other <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>). The use of <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can work as ways of packaging all game elements to be inserted at specific points during gameplay, or to modulate which game elements can appear.

The introduction of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> are less common but more important to players given their roles as <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, and while the second of these may make use of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> to match player present the original definition of the first requires its use. While this may only occur once in some games and rarely in those with <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, for games with <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay it needs to be possible to do at all times.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> if very often combined with the pattern to given players either control over which game elements are to be inserted or where they should be inserted. Ways of controlling how players can insert game elements can be through requiring <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> through paying with some <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> - something common in real-time strategy games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style>. Even when players do not have an option of not introducing new game elements, in effect making them a <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> that needs to be used, this can still be an <style="Link"><link="investments">Investment</link></style> with associated <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations if there is a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> of what to insert. <style="Link"><link="free-game-element-manipulation">Free Game Element Manipulation</link></style>  lets players to have <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> at their leisure but with the risk of changing a gaming activity into one of free play. Another, more powerful, way to combine <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> with <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> is to allow <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, i.e. not only let players insert game elements but also create these.

Besides players, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> can time when <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> should occur. When the facilitators are humans, they can also create the game elements and the rules regarding them. <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style> is a diegetic tool for motivating these insertion.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> are common forms of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. However, in games with <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> the introduction of new game elements can simply be equal to describing the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> in more detail.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> is often used to explain <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style>, and when this is improvised is the actual cause of the insertion of new game elements rather than a way to modify it. Pre-determined <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style>, for example of <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, are a way of providing progress and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> in predetermined and improvised <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. While they may not be necessary for all <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style> most likely need it to not become repetitious.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> typically make the game elements into <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> and can easily provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> during gameplay as they insert new elements into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, and when done in conjunction with <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> this can support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style>. When allowing players to add game elements are part of gameplay, the pattern easily support <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> since players can introduce the new game elements to interact or build upon the already present ones. When players can populate whole <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> through <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> this gives rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, the <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> of <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> due to <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> can be problematic regarding <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.

By pacing the introduction of game elements, <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> can easily provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> that can insert game elements embodying new rules, this can also give <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>. When game elements inserted are not part of the original definitions of possible game elements, the insertion can be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="extra-game-input">Extra-Game Input</link></style>.

When players have some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style>, this provides them <style="Link"><link="framed-freedom">Framed Freedom</link></style>, which becomes greater when they also create the elements and the rules surrounding them. If there are several different game elements to select from, the <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> is a way to give players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> but since there is typically also a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> to this (either if the wrong game element was chosen or if the use of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> to allow the insertion was wise) they are then also <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>. This also gives rise to a need for <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style>. However, handling <style="CurrentLink">Game Element Insertion</style> can also create <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style> for the players.
